item.description:
Why Women Won the Nobel Peace Prize

 

 The event is open to the public.

 

Presented by The Harvard University Institute of Politics, Carr Center for Human Rights Policy, Center for Public Leadership and the Women and Public Policy Program.

 

Wednesday, January 11, 2012, 6-7:30pm
John F. Kennedy, Jr. Forum
Littauer Building, 1st Floor
John F. Kennedy School of Government
Harvard University
79 JFK Street
Cambridge, MA 02138

:: :: ::

 

http://www.hks.harvard.edu/cchrp/events/2012/month01/IOP_Forum_Invitation_Jan_11.pdf

With the recent awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to three women leaders, policymakers are beginning to acknowledge that women are essential to peace and security. How have women worldwide mobilized, before and after this historic event, to convince those in power to heed their voices and ensure their participation? How can decision-makers draw on the underutilized resources and skills that women bring to the table?

For the 13th annual forum in this “Inclusive Security” series, join six women leaders describing how they work to end violent conflict. Ambassador Swanee Hunt, Eleanor Roosevelt Lecturer in Public Policy, will moderate the discussion with participants from Afghanistan, Israel, Pakistan, Palestine, South Sudan, and Sudan.

The forum will provide an opportunity to hear firsthand how women are waging peace within their communities and across conflict lines all over the globe. The discussion will be opened to the audience.
item.name: Why Women Won the Nobel Peace Prize
